Title: Putting Water at the Centre of Nuclear Energy History: NUCLEARWATERS

This project, NUCLEARWATERS, proposes a paradigm-shifting approach to the history of nuclear energy by reframing it as a history of water. Challenging traditional narratives, we argue that nuclear energy is fundamentally a hydraulic technology, rooted in centuries of hydraulic engineering and the development of hydraulic civilizations. Through a comprehensive and interdisciplinary investigation, we will examine the historical water-manipulating technologies and conceptions of wet and dry risks that have shaped the nuclear industry.

Our hypothesis is that a water-centred history will resolve key riddles in nuclear energy history, providing a more nuanced understanding of the sector's development and its environmental and social implications. The project is structured into six work packages, each exploring a distinct theme: the nuclear-hydraulic engineering community, Soviet Union nuclear waters, the Rhine Valley nuclearized river basin, Japan's atomic coastscapes, and the Baltic Sea region.

By revising nuclear energy history through a water-centric lens, this project aims to make significant contributions to the fields of history of technology and environmental history. Furthermore, its findings will inform and enrich the public debate on nuclear energy in Europe and beyond, providing a more informed and nuanced understanding of the sector's past, present, and future. Ultimately, NUCLEARWATERS seeks to transform our understanding of nuclear energy, highlighting the critical role of water in its development and operation.
